titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Peter Safar Papers, 1950-2003 UA.90.F102
titlestmt.author: Kallie Sheets.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:07:11 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of Peter Safar, a distinguished professor of the University of Pittsburgh. The material includes correspondence between Safar and colleagues, meetings and conferences attended and created by Safar, organization and committee information, and copies of his publications. Also included are some of Safar's personal affects including awards given to Safar and his personal briefcase.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Peter Safar Papers, 1950-2003, UA.90.F102, University of Pittsburgh Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Peter Safar Papers, 1950-2003, UA.90.F102, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Kallie Sheets in 2017.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Peter Safar was born into a family of medical professionals in Vienna, Austria, on April 12, 1924. He graduated from the University of Vienna in 1948 and a year later married his wife Eva while also moving to Hartford, Connecticut, to attend training at Yale University. In 1952 he trained at the University of Pennsylvania in Anesthesiology and in 1954 became Chief of Anesthesiology at Baltimore City Hospital, currently John Hopkins Bayview Medical Center. While there, he worked to create the ABCs of Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) which became the standard technique that was taught to medical professionals and lay people.

In 1961 he came to the University of Pittsburgh where he remained until his death in 2003. While in Pittsburgh he created many organizations to aid in critical care medicine, disaster medicine and the advancement of CPR. After the death of his daughter in 1966 Safar helped found the Freedom House Enterprise Ambulance Service, which provided one of the first services with trained Emergency Medical Technicians (EMT) to administer prehospital care. In 1979 he founded the International Resuscitation Research Center, currently the University of Pittsburgh Safar Center for Resuscitation Research, where he focused on Cardiopulmonary Cerebral Resuscitation (CPCR). Late in his career, Safar focused his research on reanimation.

Throughout his career, Safar received numerous awards. While at the University of Pittsburgh, he was awarded the honor of distinguished professorship for his contributions to the field of medicine, nationally and internationally. He was also given awards from the American Red Cross and became an honorary member of many foreign societies, like the Japan Society of Anesthesiology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of Peter Safar, a distinguished professor at the University of Pittsburgh. Included is personal and professional correspondence between Safar and his colleagues, as well as material pertaining to Safar's participation in several conferences and organizations. The collection also contains many of Safar's published articles and manuals, as well as research files. The final series of this collection contains awards and information about Safar and his contribution to the world of medicine.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access to files in Series I. Correspondence requires a signed Confidentiality Agreement due to the presence of incidental health care information.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Safar Center for Resuscitation Research in July 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes personal and professional correspondence between Peter Safar and his colleagues and associates, including fellows who were a part of the Safar Center. The series has been broken into five subseries and their organization has been maintained in their original order. Some of the correspondence within this series is written in languages other than English, including Spanish, German and Chinese. Additionally, access to the files in this series has been restricted due to the presence of personal identifiable or personal health information and require a signed confidentiality agreement to access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence between Peter Safar and colleagues. Much of this communication consists of Safar giving advice to others regarding the treatment of patients and the correct way to preform procedures. The records are arranged alphabetically by the correspondent's name and includes some restricted material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes information on the fellows who were a part of the Safar Center. It is arranged alphabetically, contains some restricted material and also includes correspondence between Safar and the individual fellows.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence between Peter Safar and the colleagues that were a part of his regular professional life. It is arranged alphabetically and includes some restricted material.

did.unittitle: Bonica, John J. and Tom Hornbein
Weil, Max Harry - Acid Base Grant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence between Peter Safar and various colleagues. The records are arranged by personal, professional, and foreign correspondence and then chronologically. Some folders contain material that is restricted and in languages other than English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence which Peter Safar had arranged by topic. Some folders contain restricted material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains files regarding meetings and conferences attended by Safar, some of which he helped to organize or served as a speaker. Included are correspondence, programs and pamphlets for these conferences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information about Peter Safar's participation in a variety of organizations and committees. Much of this work is concerned with his efforts nationally to create emergency medical services (EMS) bills and the standardization of emergency care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains copies of many of Peter Safar's publications. These include journal articles, manuals and also research completed by Safar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains journal articles that were published by Peter Safar. They are organized by the year of publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains manuals and reports contributed to or written by Peter Safar. The manual entitled Cardio-Pulmonary Cerebral Reanimation is a Spanish translation of a Safar work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the research conducted by Peter Safar for various projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes files regarding the legacy of Peter Safar, as well as biographies written about him. It also includes a scrapbook and information about Safar's time in Baltimore and his work on the creation of the ABC's of CPR. The contents of Peter Safar's briefcase and information regarding his memorialization are also included within this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains biographical sketches of Peter Safar used in publications, conferences and lectures. Other files pertain to articles, documentaries and other recognitions of Safar's contributions to medicine.

National Institute of Health Biographical Sketch
Society of Critical Care Medicine Lifetime Achievement Award

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains information on the early years of Peter Safar's work. It includes lab notebooks, a guestbook for the Baltimore City Hospital, and a scrapbook of his work while developing CPR. The scrapbook contains newspaper clippings and photographs of CPR demonstrations on paralized volunteers, as well as emergency personnel performing CPR on patients in distress.

did.unittitle: Photos from Scrapbook, Baltimore City Hospital
Photos from Scrapbook, Baltimore Firefighters Performing Resuscitation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes awards that Peter Safar received for his work from a variety of institutions, including the University of Pittsburgh and international medical organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains information and memorabilia regarding the legacy of Peter Safar. It includes a scrapbook of articles written about him after his death and pamphlets from the Safar Symposium and Lecture Series which was created in his memory. This subseries also includes a paper by Carnegie Mellon University student Andrew Simpson that was written about the work of Peter Safar.

did.unittitle: Alliance of the Germanic Societies of Pittsburgh, Recognition Luncheon
Transporting Lazarus: EMS Policy Making and Professionalization, Andrew T. Simpson, Carnegie Mellon University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the contents of Peter Safar's briefcase. All of the material within the briefcase has been grouped together and filed by topic.
